Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Experimental Chaos and Complexity 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to support participation by students and early career researchers, including members of under-represented groups, in the mathematical and physical sciences at the 14th Experimental Chaos and Complexity Conference (ECC 2016) to be held May 16-19, 2016 in Alberta, Canada. ECC 2016 will bring together an international group of researchers to improve the scientific understanding of complex systems such as the cardiac electrical system, the brain, energy and the power grid, social systems, earthquakes, and climate. The objective of ECC 2016 is to encourage and facilitate the collaboration of experimental and applied research in mathematics, physics, engineering, neuroscience, chemistry, and biology.

ECC 2016 highlights new results in the study of complex systems at a variety of scales. The goal is to bring together experimentalists and applied researchers to study various aspects of of nonlinear dynamics, chaos, and complexity. Examples of applications where this type of collaboration has been successful include the cardiac electrical system, the brain, energy and the power grid, social systems, earthquakes, and climate. These systems can display chaotic dynamics, in that small changes in inputs or features of the system can cause large changes in behavior. The study of complexity and chaos by mathematicians, physicists, engineers, chemists, biologists, and neuroscientists has led to the ability to understand and control chaotic systems in areas ranging from control of cardiac chaos to improved efficiency in combustion systems. The award gives students and early career researchers, including members of under-represented groups, the opportunity to attend and participate in this conference, with the hope that it inspires new research directions and collaborations for this group.

Conference web site: http://wcm.ucalgary.ca/ecc2016/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported travel of a diverse, inclusive group of sixteen United States scientists (in addition to the PI) to attend the 14th Experimental Chaos and Complexity Conference, held in May 2016 at Banff, Alberta, Canada. This international conference, held in alternate years, brings together an interdisciplinary group of approximately 100 mathematicians, computer scientists, physicists, electrical engineers and other scientists to explore and advance the understanding of the dynamics of a variety of complex systems.   Despite differences among these systems, their dynamics can be described and understood through a common set of mathematical techniques in non-linear mathematical dynamics.  Major themes included stability of power grid, which is growing more complex, dynamics of the brain and artificial neural nets, and causality and prediction in ecological systems, especially fisheries which are under stress from climate change and supply much of the world’s protein, all topics of present and growing importance, in which mathematical theory of dynamics on networks plays a central role and makes critical contributions.

Additional broader impacts. This group of United States scientists included significant representation from underserved populations: six women, two African-Americans, one Hispanic and one Asian/Pacific Islander, many of whom would not have otherwise been able to participate in this conference. Nine students in this group received key international experience early in their scientific careers. Three faculty came from primarily undergraduate institutions, whose important role has been recognized by the NSF program in Research in Undergraduate Institutions; one of whom recently submitted her own NSF proposal. It can be reasonably concluded that this project advanced diversity and inclusiveness in the community of US scientists active in dynamical systems.
